A scientist sacked from The Christie for failing to ensure blood transfusion equipment was properly cleaned has been struck off. 
Hema Shah worked in the Blood Transfusion Laboratory at the Christie Pathology Partnership and was in charge of supervising biomedical staff. 
In 2014, concerns were raised by colleagues about the standard of her work and as a result Ms Shah was dismissed. 
The case was referred to the Health Care Professions Council (HCPC) and an investigation was launched. Read More Two men handed gangbos in wake of Salford shootings are jailed for breaching orders 
At a HCPC panel hearing in August last year, it was heard that between November 2013 and July 2014, Ms Shah did not ensure that fridges, freezers, incubators, and other equipment were properly cleaned and decontaminated. 
She also failed to maintain adequate training for blood transfusion, or the training records for two colleagues, and did not check appropriate stock levels or regularly test the Blood Transfusion alarm system. 
The HCPC Conduct and Competence Committee originally suspended Ms Shah for six months on the grounds of misconduct, but after no communication with Ms Shah for 18 months, a further hearing last week ordered her name to be struck off the HCPC Register. The Christie (Photo: Manchester Evening News) 
HCPC panel chair Stephen Fash said: “The Panel is of the clear view that the findings made against Ms Shah by the final hearing Panel in August 2016 were very grave indeed. 
“They had very serious implications with regard to patient safety, and significant consequences for her relationships with staff for whom she was responsible.” 
A spokesperson for The Christie says that ‘at no time’ did Ms Shah’s actions result in patient harm 
They added: “Concerns were raised internally about Hema Shah’s work in July 2014. Under the organisation’s robust disciplinary procedures she was investigated for failure to follow correct process across a number of responsibilities and tasks. These included failure to maintain appropriate training records and stock taking issues. Read More Warning after smashed glass bottles found planted in grass 
“At no time did Ms Shah’s actions result in patient harm. The internal investigation identified there were sufficient lapses in following correct process that it warranted dismissal and Ms Shah was dismissed from the Christie Pathology Partnership in September 2014. 
“As required, this was reported to the regulator the HCPC.” 
Ms Shah was neither present nor represented at the hearing. Like us on Facebook
